results.title: Short orders
results.creator_credit: Hal Roach, Percy Pembroke and Hal Roach Studios
results.brief_description: Stan Laurel stars in this silent film as a harried waiter who must deal with customers who have issues with the quality of the food and service in the restaurant. Various comic situations arise. Cast: Stan Laurel, Marie Mosquini, Eddie Baker, Jack Ackroyd, Mark Jones, George Rowe

results.title: A Sporting life
results.creator_credit: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
In this Chinese language program, Professor Colin Mackerras looks at popular sports and physical activities in China. Basketball is rising in popularity and China used its excellence in Ping Pong for diplomacy when it was re-opening its doors to the world. Physical education in schools is seen as very important, while Mao Tse-tung encouraged participation in the martial arts as a way of developing a physically, morally and spiritually sound country. The program also examines the different writing styles and the emphasis on balance and movement in forming characters.

results.title: Dragons tongue. - Series 2.
results.creator_credit: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University
results.brief_description: A series of lessons in the Chinese language intended for high school students using simple vocabulary and brief dramatisations utilising the vocabulary. Includes short sections about life in modern China and a segment on Chinese writing and calligraphy. Introduced by Colin McKerras.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University

results.title: Eating out
results.creator_credit: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia) and Griffith University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
The eating habits of the Chinese are illustrated through filmed and dramatised segments. We see different kinds of restaurants, factory canteens, and a Chinese family at home during mealtimes. The “History of Chinese” segment describes the different dialects and languages that exist in China emphasising that there is really only one written script for all of these. Vocabulary introduced covers day to day language concerned with mealtimes and shopping for food.

results.title: Siege
results.creator_credit: Julien Bryan, Frank Donovan, Frederic Ullman, International Film Foundation and RKO Pathe Pictures
results.brief_description: Famous documentary by Julien Bryan on the invasion of Poland by the German army in September 1939 - the attack that began World War II. It captures, with powerful images, the terror and desperation of the refugees and the immense destruction in the cities and towns. Depicts the destructive effect on the lives of the people. An important work that shows how unprepared Poland was to face the German war machine. Depicts the first week of WWII, and includes quite graphic footage.

results.title: The Neighbourhood
results.creator_credit: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
Professor Colin Mackerras looks at the ways in which the Chinese live in community in neighbourhoods. Houses are often concealed behind walls with gate access and arranged around a courtyard. One large extended family may occupy the houses or a few different families may live in this arrangement. There is a communal kitchen facility and the area is supervised by a Resident’s Committee. This program also looks at the history of the evolution of Chinese writing into a single script.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University

results.title: Shopping
results.creator_credit: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
Professor Colin Mackerras explores the shopping habits of the Beijing people. Since the liberalisation of the Chinese economy, there has been a huge increase in the variety of goods for sale and the ways of selling - from markets to privately and collectively owned shops. Three dramatised segments illustrate different aspects of shopping, while the short section on calligraphy introduces the new simplified characters.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University

results.title: Siberia to the Silk Road
results.creator_credit: Greg Grainger, Grainger Maynard and Maynard
results.brief_description: Only weeks before the August 1991 coup in Moscow, Australian Greg Grainger embarked upon a ten thousand kilometre odyssey across the U.S.S.R., through Siberia and Central Asia, observing the lives of people at a time of extraordinary change. We observe Russia’ first ever presidential elections, visiting a polling station as Boris Yeltsin makes his historical win. A look at the lives of ordinary people in a time of extraordinary changes. See the stunning beauty of a Siberian summer, journey thousands of kilometres on the Trans Siberian Railway, drink vodka with soldiers and travel the legendary Silk Road through Uzbekistan, visiting ancient cities such as Bukhara and Samarkand.

See the stunning beauty of a Siberian summer, journey thousands of kilometres on the Trans Siberian Railway, drink vodka with soldiers and travel the legendary Silk Road through Uzbekistan, visiting ancient cities such as Bukhara and Samarkand.

results.title: Si Spain!
results.creator_credit: Thayer Soule and Hughes Leisure Group
results.brief_description: Filmmaker Thayer Soule takes us on a personal journey through Spain; capturing its colourful history and observing how that past has been integrated into the present. Soule travels through the quiet beauty of Castile, visits the Great Mosque in Cordoba with its 800 arches, treks through the snow-capped peaks of the Pyrenees and experiences the sights and sounds of a bullfight. The music, dancing and culture of Spain is vividly captured in this interesting personal travelogue.

results.title: Getting around
results.creator_credit: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
In this Chinese language program, Professor Colin Mackerras explores the Public Transport system in Beijing. This is heavily used as cars are a rarity. Buses are in great demand and overcrowded. Trains are more modern and luxurious by comparison, while bicycles are by far the most common form of transport. This episode illustrates the vocabulary and protocols required to use the Public Transport system effectively. Presents a sequence looking at the history of the Chinese Language and the confusion which can arise when words sound the same but have different meaning.
